title: The Secret Hand Fan Language of the Victorian Era

steps.title: Pulling across the cheek: “I love you.”
steps.content: Pulling across the cheek: “I love you.” Slowly drawing your fan across your cheek while you lock eyes with your significant other or crush is a discreet way to tell them that you love them. [1] X Research source Variation : Opening the fan and covering the lower half of the face, leaving the eyes exposed.

steps.title: Near the heart: “You’ve won my love.”
steps.content: Near the heart: “You’ve won my love.” Another way to coyly tell your lover that they have your heart and that you love them is to place the open fan over your heart. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Kept shut: “Do you love me?”
steps.content: Kept shut: “Do you love me?” To ask if someone is interested in you or loves you, simply hold the fan shut in your hands.

steps.title: Placing the handle on the lips: “Kiss me.”
steps.content: Placing the handle on the lips: “Kiss me.” If you want your significant other or crush to kiss you , tap the handle of the fan to your lips and briefly hold it there. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Closed and touching the right eye: “When can I see you?”
steps.content: Closed and touching the right eye: “When can I see you?” If you want to ask someone when you can expect to see them again without prying eyes noticing, hold the fan closed and tap it against your right eye.

steps.title: In front of face with right hand: “Follow me.”
steps.content: In front of face with right hand: “Follow me.” If you want to talk to someone privately or simply get away from others, ask your significant other or friend to follow you by holding the fan open in front of your face with your right hand.

steps.title: In front of face with left hand: “I want to get to know you.”
steps.content: In front of face with left hand: “I want to get to know you.” If you’re intrigued by someone at a party, hold the fan open in front of your face with your left hand to let them know that you want to get to know them better.

steps.title: Kept open in front of the body: “Wait for me.”
steps.content: Kept open in front of the body: “Wait for me.” To ask someone to stop and wait for you, hold the fan open in front of your body.

steps.title: Tapping closed fan with finger: “I want to speak to you.”
steps.content: Tapping closed fan with finger: “I want to speak to you.” To get someone’s attention and let them know you want to talk to them, close the fan and tap the top of it with your finger. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Open in left hand: “Come talk to me.”
steps.content: Open in left hand: “Come talk to me.” If you want someone specific to approach you and speak with you, simply hold the fan open in your left hand and look their way.

steps.title: Closed fan twirling in left hand: “We are being watched.”
steps.content: Closed fan twirling in left hand: “We are being watched.” If you’re having a private conversation with someone and notice that someone else is spying and watching you, let your conversation partner know by twisting and rotating the fan in your left hand while closed.

steps.title: Open and covering left ear: “Don’t give away our secret.”
steps.content: Open and covering left ear: “Don’t give away our secret.” If you just told someone a secret or you’re worried that they’ll spill it during a conversation, open up your fan and cover your left ear with it to warn them not to say anything. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Open, held behind head: “Don’t forget me.”
steps.content: Open, held behind head: “Don’t forget me.” If you’re saying goodbye to your significant other or crush, open up your fan and hold it behind your head to ask them not to forget you.

steps.title: Shutting slowly: “I will marry you.”
steps.content: Shutting slowly: “I will marry you.” Whether you want to accept your significant other’s proposal or simply let them know that marriage is on the table, hold the fan open and then slowly shut it.

steps.title: Slowly fanning: “I am married.”
steps.content: Slowly fanning: “I am married.” To let interested parties know that you’re taken and married, slowly fan yourself with the fan open wide. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Quickly fanning: “I am engaged.”
steps.content: Quickly fanning: “I am engaged.” To let people know that you’re currently engaged to be married, quickly fan yourself with the fan wide open.

steps.title: Twirling in right hand: “I love another.”
steps.content: Twirling in right hand: “I love another.” If someone’s interested in you but you want to let them know that someone else has your heart, rotate and twist the fan in your right hand while it’s closed.

steps.title: Lowering it: “We will be friends.”
steps.content: Lowering it: “We will be friends.” To tell someone that you like them and want to be friends , simply lower it from your face and let it hang by your side in your hand. [7] X Research source In Victorian times, women would also drop their fans to get someone’s attention.

steps.title: Closed, pulling through hand: “I hate you.”
steps.content: Closed, pulling through hand: “I hate you.” To let someone know that you dislike or despise them, close your fan and draw it through your hand. Hopefully, they’ll get the message and leave you alone.

steps.title: Opening and closing: “You are cruel.”
steps.content: Opening and closing: “You are cruel.” If someone upset or offended you, open and close your fan several times to let them know that they’re being mean. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Closed and resting on left ear: “Go away.”
steps.content: Closed and resting on left ear: “Go away.” When someone is bothering you and you don’t want to speak to them anymore, hold the fan closed and tap it against your left ear.

steps.title: Open in right hand: “You are too willing.”
steps.content: Open in right hand: “You are too willing.” If someone is acting too eager or ready to do something without really thinking about it, hold your fan open in your right hand to tell them to slow down and think before they act.

steps.title: Pulling across forehead: “You’ve changed.”
steps.content: Pulling across forehead: “You’ve changed.” If you haven’t seen someone in a while or they’re simply acting different, draw the fan over your forehead while it’s partially open. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Pulling across eyes: “I’m sorry.”
steps.content: Pulling across eyes: “I’m sorry.” To apologize to someone, close your fan and draw it across your eyes. This lets them know that you’re sorry.

steps.title: Open with hands together: “Forgive me.”
steps.content: Open with hands together: “Forgive me.” To ask someone to forgive you for something you did, keep the fan open and hold it with both of your hands clasped together. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Closed, resting on right cheek: “Yes.”
steps.content: Closed, resting on right cheek: “Yes.” To quickly tell someone “Yes,” close your fan and tap it against your right cheek. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Resting on left cheek: “No.”
steps.content: Resting on left cheek: “No.” If you need to tell someone “No,” close your fan and tap it against your left cheek.

steps.title: Open, keeping pinky finger extended: “Goodbye.”
steps.content: Open, keeping pinky finger extended: “Goodbye.” When you’re ending a conversation with someone or ready to leave the function, hold the fan open with your pinky finger extended (as if you’re waving it) to say “Goodbye.”

steps.title: Hand fans gained popularity in Europe in the 16th century.
steps.content: Hand fans gained popularity in Europe in the 16th century. Around the 1500s, hand fans became a staple among women in royal courts across Europe. Fans weren’t just a fashion statement or used to stay cool—they were seen as feminine and flirtatious tools that allowed women to express themselves and communicate. For instance, women used their fans to draw an admirer’s attention, encourage their advances, or playfully tease them. [12] X Research source While hand fans were only available to the nobility, they communicated status within these upper social circles. How well a woman could wave and brandish her fan, as well as how stylish her fan was, signaled her class and elegance. The hand fan started to fall out of popularity in the early 1800s. Fans became easier to produce, allowing middle-class women to take up the trend. Since the fans were no longer a sign of privilege, noble women ditched them.

steps.title: The fan language was first recorded in 1827.
steps.content: The fan language was first recorded in 1827. It’s thought that the “secret” language of the fan was actually an open secret in the 1700s and 1800s, with most people knowing that certain moves meant certain things. However, the first written record of the language was published in 1827 by the Parisian fan maker Duvelleroy. While fans were falling out of favor with the upper class at this time, the publication re-popularized the fans among the nobility. [13] X Research source In fact, Duvelleroy became the official fan maker for Queen Victoria in England. [14] X Research source It’s unclear if the language of the fan was actually a real language . Many scholars believe Duvelleroy made up the language for their publication, which was a way for them to make fans exciting again and increase their sales (and it worked!).

steps.title: The hand fan was first created and used in Ancient Egypt.
steps.content: The hand fan was first created and used in Ancient Egypt. The first hand fans were used about 4,000 years ago in Egypt. Hand fans were primarily used in religious ceremonies and by the nobility, as they were seen as sacred symbols of power. They were also used to stay cool and keep away bugs. [15] X Research source The first hand fans were rigid and typically circular or oval. They were often adorned with jewels or feathers. Hand fans were also widely used by Ancient Greeks, Romans, Persians, and Hebrews.

steps.title: The folding fan was invented in Japan and spread to China and India.
steps.content: The folding fan was invented in Japan and spread to China and India. The first folding hand fans were used in Japan around the 7th century CE, where people from every social class used them to stay cool. Folding fans spread to China and India a few centuries later. [16] X Research source It wasn’t until the 16th century that Europeans brought the folding fan into the upper levels of European society. [17] X Research source
